children.subject: For sake of discussion; we should note why this requirement exists. There's just too many intended CS majors coming in and not enough resources; no matter how bad it sounds, I think the department needs to focus on trying to provide the best for those who can attain the CS major, rather than try to let more people in and try and provide more resources for those who are unable to keep up. It sounds bad, but now there's so many resources that can be used to try and reach the requirement: HKN/UPE tutoring, CSM Sections, etc. Its up to the students now w/ these student organizations to try and make the requirement attainable; the department has their own problems now

I don't think the advice 'apply to EECS if you're sure you want to do CS' is always good.
In high school, knew I wanted to do CS but I also knew my qualifications on my college app were nowhere near EECS standards of admission, so I intentionally applied for L&S CS for better chance of getting in, which worked out well. Luckily, strength of your college app is not very indicative of how well you do here -- I barely got into Berkeley (spring admit) yet got an A+ in 61A, 61B and an A in 70.
This is actually why I think the 3.3 GPA requirement is a good thing: you get into the CS major based on how well you do in CS.
(I would say in an ideal world, there shouldn't be a GPA requirement, but that's simply not feasible... It's like how it would be nice if everyone who applied to Berkeley could get in, but that just won't work, there's not enough space or money).

Oh I totally agree with you anon, I actually think high school stats are just a reflection of privilege rather than actual ability. That comment was more directed to OP who is complaining about already getting into Berkeley and not wanting to apply to the major.
There's also plenty of people who prefer CS over EECS, perhaps because of double-majors and such, or because of the difference in breadth requirements.

"If you applied to Berkeley as a Computer Science major and was admitted, should you have to reapply again?"

You were considered undeclared when you applied to Berkeley. The fact that you put CS had no impact on your acceptance; your application was considered the same as a humanities major.

To be blunt, if you really knew you wanted to do CS, you could/should have applied in as EECS, and not have to deal with declaring.
Can we also have an option for people who realize that this isn't something that should be decided by voting, but based on logistics and administrative capacity?
Just when I thought I couldn't appreciate Steven Bi anymore than I already did....

Sorry, but could you also make another poll to check how many would favor increasing the GPA cap? I know many people (myself included) who would vote for an increase in GPA cap - say, to 3.5 like it was in years past.
Are there any benefits to lowering the cap..?

history.content:
If you applied to Berkeley as a Computer Science major and was admitted, should you have to reapply again?

Would you sign a petition to lower the CS 3.3 GPA requirement (since this is the only major in L&S) with such a high GPA requirement?
history.subject: Would you sign a petition to lower the CS 3.3 GPA requirement?
